title: Psalms Chapter 28 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 28 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 28 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 28.

questions.question: Who is the psalmist crying unto in Psalms 28:1?
questions.correctAnswer: O LORD my rock
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:1 states, 'Unto thee will I cry, O LORD my rock.'

questions.question: What does the psalmist ask God not to do in Psalms 28:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Be silent to me
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'be not silent to me: lest, if thou be silent to me, I become like them that go down into the pit.'

questions.question: When does the psalmist say he lifts up his hands according to Psalms 28:2?
questions.correctAnswer: When he cries unto God
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:2 states, 'Hear the voice of my supplications, when I cry unto thee, when I lift up my hands toward thy holy oracle.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 28:3, how do the workers of iniquity speak to their neighbors?
options: Peacefully but with mischief in their hearts
questions.correctAnswer: Peacefully but with mischief in their hearts
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'which speak peace to their neighbours, but mischief is in their hearts.'

questions.question: What does the psalmist ask God to give the wicked according to Psalms 28:4?
questions.correctAnswer: According to their deeds
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:4 states, 'Give them according to their deeds, and according to the wickedness of their endeavours.'

questions.question: Why will God destroy the wicked according to Psalms 28:5?
options: Because they regard not the works of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Because they regard not the works of the LORD
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'Because they regard not the works of the LORD, nor the operation of his hands, he shall destroy them.'

questions.question: What blessing does the psalmist give to the LORD in Psalms 28:6?
questions.correctAnswer: Blessed be the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:6 says, 'Blessed be the LORD, because he hath heard the voice of my supplications.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 28:7, what is the LORD to the psalmist?
questions.correctAnswer: My strength and my shield
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'The LORD is my strength and my shield; my heart trusted in him, and I am helped.'

questions.question: What is the psalmist's heart doing in Psalms 28:7 after trusting in the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Greatly rejoicing
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:7 says, 'therefore my heart greatly rejoiceth.'

questions.question: Who is called the LORD's anointed in Psalms 28:8?
questions.correctAnswer: His anointed
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:8 states, 'The LORD is their strength, and he is the saving strength of his anointed.'

questions.question: What does the psalmist ask the LORD to do for His people in Psalms 28:9?
options: Save thy people and bless thine inheritance
Send them away to foreign lands
Make them kings over the nations
questions.correctAnswer: Save thy people and bless thine inheritance
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'Save thy people, and bless thine inheritance: feed them also, and lift them up for ever.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 28:5 says God will build up the wicked.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:5 states that God will destroy them and not build them up.

questions.question: True or False: The psalmist says he will praise God with his song in Psalms 28:7.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:7 says, 'with my song will I praise him.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 28:3 describes the wicked as honest and straightforward with their neighbors.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:3 describes the wicked as speaking peace to their neighbors but having mischief in their hearts.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 28:2: 'Hear the voice of my ________, when I cry unto thee...'
questions.correctAnswer: supplications
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:2 begins with 'Hear the voice of my supplications, when I cry unto thee...'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 28 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 28 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer feels abandoned and silent prayers. Based on Psalms 28:1, what biblical truth would you share to encourage them?
options: God is our rock and hears our cries; His silence leads to spiritual danger
We should stop praying if God seems silent
God only answers prayers in church
Silence from God means He has rejected us
questions.correctAnswer: God is our rock and hears our cries; His silence leads to spiritual danger
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:1 teaches that the LORD is our rock and that if He were silent, one could become like those who descend into the pit, emphasizing the importance of trusting God even in silence.

questions.question: How does Psalms 28:2 demonstrate the importance of prayer and personal devotion in a believer's life?
options: It shows lifting hands and crying out to God is a meaningful expression of faith
Prayer is only necessary during church services
God prefers silent meditation over vocal prayer
Supplications should be private and never public
questions.correctAnswer: It shows lifting hands and crying out to God is a meaningful expression of faith
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:2 illustrates that lifting hands toward God's holy oracle while crying out is a sincere act of prayer and devotion, encouraging believers to seek God earnestly.

questions.question: According to Psalms 28:3, what warning is given about associating with the wicked in daily life?
options: Avoid being led away with those who speak peace but harbor mischief
It is safe to trust everyone who speaks kindly
Wickedness is only harmful if openly declared
Associating with the wicked builds character
questions.correctAnswer: Avoid being led away with those who speak peace but harbor mischief
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:3 warns against being drawn away by the wicked who deceptively speak peace but have evil intentions, encouraging believers to maintain integrity and avoid bad influences.

questions.question: A believer struggles with forgiveness towards someone who has harmed them. How does Psalms 28:4 teach about God's justice in dealing with the wicked?
options: God will give the wicked according to their deeds and render to them their due
God ignores the deeds of the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: God will give the wicked according to their deeds and render to them their due
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:4 emphasizes that God will judge the wicked based on their actions, reassuring believers that divine justice prevails and they can trust God for righteous judgment.

questions.question: How does Psalms 28:5 encourage believers to remain faithful when others disregard God's works?
options: God will destroy those who ignore His works but will build up the faithful
God rewards only those who ignore worldly troubles
Ignoring God’s works leads to blessings
questions.correctAnswer: God will destroy those who ignore His works but will build up the faithful
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:5 explains that those who disregard God's works face destruction, while God strengthens and builds up those who trust Him, encouraging perseverance in faith.

questions.question: What reason does Psalms 28:6 give for praising the LORD according to personal experience?
options: Because He has heard the voice of our supplications
Because He is distant and silent
questions.correctAnswer: Because He has heard the voice of our supplications
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:6 expresses praise to God specifically because He listens to and answers prayers, encouraging believers to be grateful and worshipful.

questions.question: According to Psalms 28:7, how does trusting the LORD affect a believer's heart and life?
options: It brings strength, help, rejoicing, and praise
It leads to constant fear and anxiety
Trusting God has no effect on emotions
questions.correctAnswer: It brings strength, help, rejoicing, and praise
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:7 states that trusting the LORD results in strength, protection, help, a rejoicing heart, and song of praise, showing the practical impact of faith in daily life.

questions.question: How does Psalms 28:8 describe God's role for His anointed and His people in terms of strength?
options: God is their strength and the saving strength of His anointed
God leaves His anointed to rely on themselves
Strength comes only from human effort
questions.correctAnswer: God is their strength and the saving strength of His anointed
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:8 highlights that God is the source of strength and salvation for His chosen ones, encouraging believers to depend on Him rather than their own abilities.

questions.question: A church leader is seeking guidance on how to serve their congregation effectively. Based on Psalms 28:9, what practical biblical teaching can be shared?
options: Pray for God's blessing, provision, and uplifting care for the people and His inheritance
Focus only on administrative tasks and ignore spiritual needs
Rely solely on human wisdom without prayer
questions.correctAnswer: Pray for God's blessing, provision, and uplifting care for the people and His inheritance
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:9 calls for praying to God to save, bless, feed, and uplift His people continually, teaching leaders the importance of spiritual intercession and care.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 28:1, if God is silent to us, we become like those who go down into the pit.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:1 clearly states that if God is silent, the psalmist fears becoming like those who descend into the pit, symbolizing spiritual destruction.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 28:7 indicates that trusting in the LORD brings help and causes the heart to greatly rejoice.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:7 teaches that trusting the LORD results in help and great rejoicing in the heart, confirmed by the psalmist's praise.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 28:3 warns us not to be drawn away with the wicked, who speak _____ to their neighbors but have mischief in their hearts.
questions.correctAnswer: peace
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:3 describes the wicked as those who speak peace to their neighbors while harboring mischief, warning believers to be discerning about influences.

questions.question: How does Psalms 28:5 inform a believer's understanding of God's judgment and encouragement to persevere?
options: God will destroy those who ignore His works but will build up the faithful
Perseverance is not rewarded by God
All will be built up regardless of their deeds
questions.correctAnswer: God will destroy those who ignore His works but will build up the faithful
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:5 contrasts the fate of the wicked and the faithful, encouraging perseverance by trusting God's just judgment.

questions.question: A believer is learning to praise God through trials. According to Psalms 28:6 and 28:7, what motivates heartfelt praise and rejoicing?
options: God hearing prayers and providing strength and help
Only praising God when life is easy
questions.correctAnswer: God hearing prayers and providing strength and help
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:6 and 28:7 together show that praise and rejoicing come from experiencing God's attentive hearing and sustaining strength.

questions.question: What practical lesson about integrity at work can be drawn from Psalms 28:4?
options: People will be judged according to their deeds, so honest work is important
Deeds do not matter as much as intentions
Work ethics are irrelevant to faith
questions.correctAnswer: People will be judged according to their deeds, so honest work is important
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:4’s principle of receiving according to one's deeds encourages believers to maintain honesty and integrity in their work.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 28 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 28.

questions.question: In Psalms 28:1, the phrase 'O LORD my rock' uses 'rock' as a metaphor. What does this metaphor primarily signify in the context of ancient Near Eastern culture and biblical literature?
options: A symbol of strength and stability
An idol worshipped by neighboring nations
A reference to a mountain where sacrifices were made
A poetic term for a desert
questions.correctAnswer: A symbol of strength and stability
questions.explanation: The metaphor 'rock' in Psalms 28:1 signifies strength and stability, reflecting God's unchanging and protective nature, a common biblical and ancient Near Eastern symbol.

questions.question: Which literary device is most prominent in Psalms 28:3 when it contrasts 'workers of iniquity' who speak peace but harbor mischief?
questions.correctAnswer: Irony
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:3 uses irony by highlighting the deceitfulness of the wicked who verbally express peace but internally plan mischief.

questions.question: According to Psalms 28:4, what principle of divine justice is expressed through the phrase 'Give them according to their deeds'?
questions.correctAnswer: Retributive justice
questions.explanation: The phrase in Psalms 28:4 reflects retributive justice, where individuals receive consequences corresponding to their actions.

questions.question: In Psalms 28:5, the psalmist mentions that the LORD 'shall destroy them, and not build them up' because they 'regard not the works of the LORD.' This reflects a theological theme consistent with which Old Testament teaching?
options: The covenantal blessing and curse principle
questions.correctAnswer: The covenantal blessing and curse principle
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:5 echoes the covenantal blessings and curses found in Deuteronomy, where obedience brings blessing and disobedience results in destruction.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'heard the voice of my supplications' in Psalms 28:6 in the broader biblical context of prayer?
options: It emphasizes God's attentiveness to heartfelt prayer
It indicates that God responds only to sacrifices
It suggests that prayer must be silent
It implies that only priests can pray effectively
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes God's attentiveness to heartfelt prayer
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:6 highlights the biblical theme that God listens attentively to sincere prayers, reinforcing the relational aspect of prayer.

questions.question: Psalms 28:7 states, 'The LORD is my strength and my shield.' How does this dual metaphor reflect the psalmist’s understanding of God's role?
options: God as both protector and source of power
questions.correctAnswer: God as both protector and source of power
questions.explanation: The metaphors in Psalms 28:7 reveal that God provides both defense (shield) and empowerment (strength) to the psalmist.

questions.question: True or False: In Psalms 28:8, the term 'his anointed' (Hebrew: mashiach) foreshadows the Messianic expectation later fulfilled in the New Testament.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:8 uses 'his anointed' which in Hebrew is 'mashiach,' a title that carries Messianic connotations later fulfilled in Christ in the New Testament.

questions.question: In Psalms 28:2, the psalmist mentions lifting up hands toward the 'holy oracle.' What does 'holy oracle' refer to in the historical and cultic context of ancient Israel?
options: The sanctuary or dwelling place of God
An idol of a neighboring deity
questions.correctAnswer: The sanctuary or dwelling place of God
questions.explanation: The term 'holy oracle' in Psalms 28:2 refers to the sacred sanctuary or temple where God's presence dwells, a place of divine communication.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the chiastic structure present in Psalms 28?
options: A call for help (verses 1-2), a plea for justice (verses 3-5), thanksgiving and trust (verses 6-7), and a blessing for the community (verses 8-9)
A historical narrative followed by a prophetic oracle
A chronological recount of David’s battles
questions.correctAnswer: A call for help (verses 1-2), a plea for justice (verses 3-5), thanksgiving and trust (verses 6-7), and a blessing for the community (verses 8-9)
questions.explanation: Psalms 28 is structured chiastically, moving from personal lament to plea for justice, followed by praise, and concluding with communal blessing.

questions.question: In Psalms 28:9, the psalmist prays for God to 'feed them also, and lift them up for ever.' This imagery most closely aligns with which biblical motif?
questions.correctAnswer: God as shepherd and sustainer
questions.explanation: The request to 'feed' and 'lift up' in Psalms 28:9 reflects the shepherd imagery common in biblical texts indicating God's care and provision.

questions.question: Psalms 28:5 mentions 'the operation of his hands.' In Hebrew poetry, what does this phrase typically emphasize about God’s role?
options: God as a mere mythic figure
questions.correctAnswer: God as creator and sustainer
questions.explanation: The phrase in Psalms 28:5 poetically highlights God's active role in creation and ongoing providence.

questions.question: In the broader canonical context, Psalms 28:7’s declaration 'my heart greatly rejoiceth' parallels which New Testament passage emphasizing joy in the Lord as strength?
questions.correctAnswer: Nehemiah 8:10
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 8:10 similarly speaks of joy in the Lord as strength, paralleling the rejoicing expressed in Psalms 28:7.

questions.question: True or False: The plea in Psalms 28:3 to 'Draw me not away with the wicked' reflects a theme of separation from evil that is consistent with wisdom literature like Proverbs.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The request in Psalms 28:3 aligns with wisdom literature such as Proverbs, which often warns against fellowship with the wicked.

questions.question: The phrase 'my heart trusted in him' (Psalms 28:7) employs which Hebrew word often translated as 'trust' or 'hope,' and what is its theological significance?
options: Chazaq, indicating strength and confidence in God
Hesed, referring to loving-kindness or covenant loyalty
questions.correctAnswer: Chazaq, indicating strength and confidence in God
questions.explanation: The Hebrew root chazaq conveys strength and confidence, underscoring the psalmist's firm reliance on God's power in Psalms 28:7.

questions.question: In Psalms 28:8, 'The LORD is their strength, and he is the saving strength of his anointed.' This verse can be seen as a typological foreshadowing of which New Testament concept?
options: Christ as the Messiah and Savior
The establishment of the Mosaic Law
questions.correctAnswer: Christ as the Messiah and Savior
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:8 foreshadows the New Testament understanding of Jesus as the Messiah ('anointed') who provides salvation and strength.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 28 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 28 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Psalms 28:1, David calls the LORD his "rock." What theological attribute of God is primarily expressed by referring to God as "my rock"?
options: God is a steadfast and unchanging protector
God is a creator of the heavens and the earth
God is a judge who punishes sinners
questions.correctAnswer: God is a steadfast and unchanging protector
questions.explanation: The metaphor of God as "my rock" in Psalms 28:1 emphasizes God's unchanging and reliable nature as a protector and refuge. This is consistent with passages like Deuteronomy 32:4, 2 Samuel 22:2-3, Isaiah 26:4, 1 Corinthians 10:4, and Romans 8:31 which affirm God's steadfastness and protection.

questions.question: According to Psalms 28:2, what action does David describe when he cries unto the LORD?
options: Lifting up his hands toward the holy oracle
questions.correctAnswer: Lifting up his hands toward the holy oracle
questions.explanation: David describes lifting up his hands toward God's holy oracle when he cries unto the LORD in Psalms 28:2. This gesture signifies earnest prayer and supplication, consistent with biblical worship practices in 1 Timothy 2:8, Psalm 63:4, Exodus 17:11, and Luke 24:50-51.

questions.question: In Psalms 28:3, David asks God not to draw him away with the wicked. What characteristic of the wicked does David highlight?
options: They speak peace to their neighbours but harbor mischief in their hearts
They are physically strong but morally weak
They are silent and do not pray
questions.correctAnswer: They speak peace to their neighbours but harbor mischief in their hearts
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:3 highlights the deceitfulness of the wicked who speak peace outwardly but harbor evil intentions inwardly. This theme aligns with Proverbs 26:24-26, Jeremiah 9:8, Matthew 7:15, and Romans 16:17 about hypocrisy and deceitful behavior.

questions.question: What does David request God to do to the wicked in Psalms 28:4?
options: Give them according to their deeds and wickedness
questions.correctAnswer: Give them according to their deeds and wickedness
questions.explanation: David asks God to repay the wicked according to their deeds and the wickedness of their endeavors in Psalms 28:4. This reflects the biblical principle of divine justice seen in passages like Proverbs 24:12, Romans 12:19, Galatians 6:7, and Revelation 22:12.

questions.question: According to Psalms 28:5, why will God destroy the wicked and not build them up?
options: Because they do not regard the works of the LORD nor the operation of His hands
Because they have no power in the land
questions.correctAnswer: Because they do not regard the works of the LORD nor the operation of His hands
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:5 states that God will destroy the wicked because they ignore His works and the operation of His hands. This reflects the biblical condemnation of unbelief and rebellion in passages such as Romans 1:20-22, Psalm 14:1, Isaiah 5:12, and Hebrews 3:12.

questions.question: What is the reason for blessing the LORD in Psalms 28:6?
options: Because He has heard the voice of David’s supplications
Because He created the heavens and the earth
Because He is merciful to the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: Because He has heard the voice of David’s supplications
questions.explanation: David blesses the LORD in Psalms 28:6 because God has heard his prayers. This shows God's attentiveness and response to prayer, consistent with 1 John 5:14, Jeremiah 33:3, Psalm 34:17, and Matthew 7:7.

questions.question: In Psalms 28:7, what two metaphors does David use to describe the LORD’s role in his life?
questions.correctAnswer: Strength and shield
questions.explanation: David calls the LORD his strength and shield in Psalms 28:7, illustrating God as both the source of power and protection. This is echoed in Exodus 15:2, Psalm 18:2, Ephesians 6:16, and 2 Samuel 22:3.

questions.question: According to Psalms 28:7, what is the result of trusting in the LORD?
options: The heart is greatly rejoiced and praises Him with song
questions.correctAnswer: The heart is greatly rejoiced and praises Him with song
questions.explanation: Trusting in the LORD leads to great rejoicing and praise as stated in Psalms 28:7. This reflects the joy in salvation seen in Nehemiah 8:10, Psalm 33:21, Philippians 4:4, and Isaiah 12:6.

questions.question: In Psalms 28:8, who is described as having the LORD as their strength and saving strength?
questions.correctAnswer: God’s anointed
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:8 describes the LORD as the strength and saving strength of His anointed, referring typically to the Messiah or appointed leaders. This messianic theme is consistent with Psalm 2:2, Isaiah 61:1, Luke 4:18, and Hebrews 1:9.

questions.question: In Psalms 28:9, what does David ask the LORD to do for His people and inheritance?
options: Save, bless, feed, and lift them up forever
Ignore their enemies and remain silent
Make them rulers over other nations
questions.correctAnswer: Save, bless, feed, and lift them up forever
questions.explanation: David petitions in Psalms 28:9 for God to save, bless, feed, and uphold His people perpetually. This aligns with God’s covenantal care seen in Psalm 23:1-3, Deuteronomy 33:12, John 10:27-28, and Romans 8:38-39.

questions.question: How does Psalms 28:1 express the consequence if God remains silent to David’s cry?
options: David would become like those who go down into the pit
David would be forgotten by God
questions.correctAnswer: David would become like those who go down into the pit
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:1 warns that if God is silent, David fears becoming like those who descend into the pit, symbolizing death or destruction. This imagery is consistent with Job 17:13, Psalm 30:3, Ezekiel 32:18-32, and Revelation 20:14.

questions.question: Which aspect of God’s justice is emphasized in Psalms 28:4-5 regarding the wicked?
options: God repays people according to their deeds and destroys those who disregard His works
God gives the wicked a second chance
God blesses the wicked to repent
questions.correctAnswer: God repays people according to their deeds and destroys those who disregard His works
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:4-5 teaches that God executes justice by repaying the wicked according to their deeds and punishing those who do not acknowledge His works. This is corroborated by Ecclesiastes 12:14, Jeremiah 17:10, Matthew 16:27, and Romans 2:6.

questions.question: What attitude towards God’s works does Psalms 28:5 indicate leads to destruction?
options: Not regarding or acknowledging the works of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Not regarding or acknowledging the works of the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:5 states that destruction comes to those who do not regard the works of the LORD. This highlights the peril of unbelief and ignoring God’s mighty acts, paralleling Romans 1:21, Psalm 10:4, Hosea 4:1, and Hebrews 3:12.

questions.question: In Psalms 28:7, what is the relationship between trusting God and being helped?
options: Trusting God results in being helped and rejoicing in the heart
Trusting God only brings future rewards
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting God results in being helped and rejoicing in the heart
questions.explanation: David declares in Psalms 28:7 that because his heart trusted in the LORD, he was helped and rejoiced greatly. This connection between trust, divine help, and joy is affirmed in Psalm 37:40, Isaiah 41:10, Proverbs 3:5-6, and Philippians 4:13.

questions.question: How does Psalms 28:8 characterize the LORD’s strength in relation to His anointed?
options: The LORD is the saving strength of His anointed
The LORD is distant from His anointed
The LORD abandons His anointed in trials
The LORD tests but does not save His anointed
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is the saving strength of His anointed
questions.explanation: Psalms 28:8 affirms that the LORD is the strength and saving power for His anointed, highlighting divine support for God’s chosen one. This is echoed in Psalm 18:50, Isaiah 42:1, Acts 10:38, and Hebrews 1:9.
